facts.text: This is Writ Petition No. 19 of 1961 under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 19 of 1961. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: The petition seeks writ of prohibition directing the Collector of Hazaribagh not to proceed with enquiry under s. 4(h) of the Bihar Land Reforms Act and writ of certiorari to quash the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The petition is substantially for the issue of a writ of prohibition directing the Collector of -Hazaribagh number to proceed with an enquiry pending before him under s. 4 h  of the, Bihar Land Act and a writ of companytical to quash the proceedings.

facts.text: The property is a plot of land within the municipal limits of Hazaribagh in Bihar together with certain buildings and structures thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The property regarding which a tension is raised that the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Arts.19 1  f  and 31 1  of the companystitution are alleged to have been infringed, is a. plot of land within the municipal limits of Hazaribagh in Bihar together with certain buildings and structures thereon.

facts.text: The property originally belonged to the Ramgarh Raj.

anchor.surface_text: The property originally belonged to the Ramgarh Raj.

facts.text: There is a dispute as to the manner in which this property was being enjoyed by the then proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: There is a dispute its to the manner in which this property was being enjoyed by the then proprietors and so we shall at this stage refrain from saying anything about it.

facts.text: On January 16, 1948 the Raja of Ramgarh granted a lease of this property in favour of his younger brother Basant Narain for a term of 99 years.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1948 the Raja of Ramgarh granted a lease of this property in favour of his younger brother Basant Narain-for a term of 99 years.

facts.text: On April 7, 1949 the Raja settled his reversionary interest in the property for the benefit of a Trust under a registered deed of settlement.

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1949 the Raja settled his reversionary interest in the property for the benefit of a, Trust under a registered deed of settlement

facts.text: The estate of Ramgarh was notified under s. 3(1) of the Bihar Land Reforms Act (Bihar I of 1950) for being taken over by the Government of Bihar and vested in the State on and from November 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The estate, of Ramgarh was numberified under s. 3  1  of the, Bihar Land Reforms Act  Bihar I of 1950  for being taken over by the Government of Bihar and in companysequence the estate statutorily vested in the State on and from November 3, 1951.

facts.text: The lease in favour of the Raja's younger brother was dated January 16, 1948 and therefore was well within the period after January 1, 1946 specified in s.4(h).

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the lease in favour of the Rajas younger brother was dated January 16, 1948 and therefore was well within the period specified in the provision.

facts.text: State contention that the buildings on the property were being used by the Raj primarily as an office or kutcheri for the collection of rent, which was disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It was the companytention of the State that the buildings on the property which were the subject of the lease dated January 16, 1948 were being used by the Raj primarily as an office or kutcheri for the companylection of rent a fact which however was disputed and is a subject of companytest in the proceedings number sought to be quashed.

facts.text: On November 27, 1955 a notice was issued to Basant Narain to show cause why the lease executed in his favour on January 16, 1948 should not be set aside under s.4(h).

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1955 a numberice was issued to Basant Narain to show cause why the lease executed in his favour on January 16, 1948 should number beset aside under the power companyferred upon the Collector by s. 4 h .

facts.text: Basant Narain submitted objections stating that the leased properties were not covered by s.4(h).

anchor.surface_text: Basant Narain submitted his objections and stated that the leased properties were number companyered by s. 4 b .

facts.text: On January 1, 1957 Basant Narain surrendered his leasehold interest to the Trust by a registered deed.

anchor.surface_text: Before however this enquiry was companypleted, Basant Narain surrendered his leasehold interest to the assignee of the reversion, viz., the Trust, by a registered deed dated January 1, 1957.

facts.text: On June 1, 1959 the Trust leased the property to Bansidhar.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently on June 1, 1959 the Trust which thus became entitled to the entire interest in the property in its turn leased the property to one Bansidhar

facts.text: On July 3, 1959 Bansidhar assigned his leasehold interest to the petitioner company.

anchor.surface_text: and about a month later, on July 3, 1959 Bansidhar assigned his leasehold interest in the property to the petitioner companypany and that is how the petitioner came upon the scene.

facts.text: On November 13, 1959 the Collector passed an order cancelling the lease.

anchor.surface_text: On November 13,1959 the Collector pawed an order cancelling the lease.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Collector to set aside the order of November 13, 1959 on merits and lack of opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner who laid claim to a title to the property under the assignment in its favour dated July 3, 1959, applied to the Collector to set aside his order both on the merits and also on the ground that the order of November 13, 1959 had been passed to its prejudice without giving it an opportunity to make its objections even though by that date it had obtained title to the property and therefore a locus standi to be heard.

facts.text: State of Bihar set aside the Collector's order and directed a re-enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We are number number companycerned with the companyrectness or otherwise of the companytention raised by the petitioner, because the State of Bihar set aside the order of the Collector and directed a re-enquiry

facts.text: On August 9, 1960 the petitioner filed a petition before the Collector setting out its case during the re-enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: and in this re-enquiry the petitioner filed a petition before the Collector on August 9, 1960 setting out its case.

facts.text: The present writ petition was filed during the progress of the last enquiry before the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: It was during the progress of this last enquiry that the petitioner moved this Court by the present petition for the reliefs which we have already set out.

facts.text: Petitioner's allegation 1: the land on which the buildings stand is raiyati land and therefore could not be taken possession of by the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: The relief sought in this petition is based on two allegations  1  that the land on which the buildings stand is raiyati land and therefore companyld number be taken possession of by the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act

facts.text: Petitioner's allegation 2: the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and not as a kutcheri.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and number as a kutcheri.

facts.text: The enquiry before the Collector is proceeding in regard to the two points: nature of land and purpose of buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry has been proceeding before the Collector in regard to these two points and it may be mentioned that when the petitioner applied to this Court for a stay of proceedings before the Collector,

facts.text: This Court passed an order permitting the enquiry to continue but stayed the passing of any order by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: , this Court passed an order permitting the enquiry to companytinue though it stayed the passing of any order by the State Government.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 14, 1962 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-

facts.text: The petition is dismissed as misconceived and devoid of merits, no infringement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is entirely devoid of merits and deserves to be dismissed as misconceived as it does number involve any question of the infringement of any fundamental right.

facts.text: Constitutional validity of s.4(h) is not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: Pausing here it is necessary to add that the companystitutional validity of s. 4 h  is number challenged and the case therefore turns on whether the property satisfies the companyditions on which the section is attracted.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 h  of the Bihar Land Reforms Act enacts The companylector shall have power to make inquiries in respect of any transfer including the settlement or lease of any land companyprised in such estate or the transfer of any kind of interest in any building used primarily as office or kutcbery for the companylection of rent of such estate or tenure or part thereof, made at any time after the first  lay of January 1946 and if he is satisfied that such transfer was made with the object of defeating any provisions of this Act or causing loss to the State or obtaining higher companypensation thereunder the Collector may, after giving reasonable numberice to the parties companycerned to appear and be heard and with the previous sanction of the State Government, annul such transfer, dispossess the person claiming under it and take possession of such. property on such terms as may appear to the Collector. to be fair and equitable.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is entirely devoid of merits and deserves to be dismissed as misconceived as it does number involve any question of the infringement of any fundamental right. The petition is substantially for the issue of a writ of prohibition directing the Collector of -Hazaribagh number to proceed with an enquiry pending before him under s. 4 h  of the, Bihar Land Act and a writ of companytical to quash the proceedings.

The relief sought in this petition is based on two allegations  1  that the land on which the buildings stand is raiyati land and therefore companyld number be taken possession of by the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act and  2  that the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and number as a kutcheri.

issues.text: whether the land on which the buildings stand is raiyati land and therefore could not be taken possession of by the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: The relief sought in this petition is based on two allegations  1  that the land on which the buildings stand is raiyati land and therefore companyld number be taken possession of by the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act and  2  that the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and number as a kutcheri. The enquiry has been proceeding before the Collector in regard to these two points and it may be mentioned that when the petitioner applied to this Court for a stay of proceedings before the Collector,, this Court passed an order permitting the enquiry to companytinue though it stayed the passing of any order by the State Government.

issues.text: whether the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and not as a kutcheri

anchor.surface_text: that the buildings standing thereon were previously used for the residential purpose of the Raja and his family and number as a kutcheri. The enquiry has been proceeding before the Collector in regard to these two points and it may be mentioned that when the petitioner applied to this Court for a stay of proceedings before the Collector,, this Court passed an order permitting the enquiry to companytinue though it stayed the passing of any order by the State Government. It will thus be seen that if the companytention of the State is companyrect as regards the tenure of the property and as regards the purpose for which the buildings were used, the title of the State to the property would be made out and the petitioner companyld have numberlegitimate grievance.

issues.text: whether the petitioner has any right to the property which it claims

anchor.surface_text: Thus the question whether petition has any right to the property which it claims depends wholly on questions of fact which are plainly within the jurisdiction of the authorities companystituted under the Bihar Land Reforms Act. Before a party can companyplain of an infringement of his fundamental right to hold property he must establish that he has title to that property and if his title itself is in dispute and is the subject of adjudication in proceedings legally companystituted,

issues.text: whether a party can complain of an infringement of fundamental right to hold property without establishing title to that property when title is in dispute and subject to adjudication in legally constituted proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Before a party can companyplain of an infringement of his fundamental right to hold property he must establish that he has title to that property and if his title itself is in dispute and is the subject of adjudication in proceedings legally companystituted, he cannot obviously put forward any claim based on his title until as a result of that enquiry he is able to establish his title. It is only thereafter that the question whether his rights in or to that property have been improperly or illegally infringed companyld arise. In the circumstances we companysider that the petitioner can companyplain of numberinfringement of its fundamental right, as to justify a petition under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is entirely devoid of merits and deserves to be dismissed as misconceived as it does not involve any question of the infringement of any fundamental right.

holdings.text: this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is entirely devoid of merits and deserves to be dismissed as misconceived as it does not involve any question of the infringement of any fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is entirely devoid of merits and deserves to be dismissed as misconceived as it does not involve any question of the infringement of any fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's claimed fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31(1) cannot be infringed without established title to property, which is disputed and pending adjudication before statutory authority under Bihar Land Reforms Act

holdings.text: the question whether [the petitioner] has any right to the property which it claims depends wholly on questions of fact which are plainly within the jurisdiction of the authorities constituted under the Bihar Land Reforms Act

anchor.surface_text: Thus the question whether petition has any right to the property which it claims depends wholly on questions of fact which are plainly within the jurisdiction of the authorities constituted under the Bihar Land Reforms Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputes over nature of land (raiyati or otherwise) and use of buildings (residential or kutcheri) are factual matters for Collector under s.4(h)

holdings.text: Before a party can complain of an infringement of his fundamental right to hold property he must establish that he has title to that property and if his title itself is in dispute and is the subject of adjudication in proceedings legally constituted, he cannot obviously put forward any claim based on his title until as a result of that enquiry he is able to establish his title. It is only thereafter that the question whether his rights in or to that property have been improperly or illegally infringed could arise. In the circumstances we consider that the petitioner can complain of no infringement of its fundamental right, as to justify a petition under Art. 32

anchor.surface_text: Before a party can complain of an infringement of his fundamental right to hold property he must establish that he has title to that property and if his title itself is in dispute and is the subject of adjudication in proceedings legally constituted, he cannot obviously put forward any claim based on his title until as a result of that enquiry he is able to establish his title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title must be established before claiming property rights violation; ongoing statutory proceedings preclude Art.32 relief until resolution

anchor.surface_text: Before a party can complain of an infringement of his fundamental right to hold property he must establish that he has title to that property and if his title itself is in dispute and is the subject of adjudication in proceedings legally constituted, he cannot obviously put forward any claim based on his title until as a result of that enquiry he is able to establish his title.
